> <@rkirsling:matrix.org> er s/library/module/ whatever

Namespace?
that too üòÖ

> <@jackworks:matrix.org> A question, why Temporal not named `Time`?

To me, temporal reads as ‚Äúabout time‚Äù rather than ‚Äútime‚Äù, so it stretches to cover ‚Äúdate‚Äù, ‚Äúmoment‚Äù, ‚Äúduration‚Äù, ‚Äúclock‚Äù, ‚Äúcalendar‚Äù, ‚Äútimezone‚Äù, ‚Äúappointment‚Äù, and ‚Äúprocrastinate‚Äù more easily. Every precedent has been tried and this one‚Äôs not the worst.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jackworks:matrix.org
A question, why Temporal not named `Time`?
To me, temporal reads as ‚Äúabout time‚Äù rather than ‚Äútime‚Äù, so it stretches to cover ‚Äúdate‚Äù, ‚Äúmoment‚Äù, ‚Äúduration‚Äù, ‚Äúclock‚Äù, ‚Äúcalendar‚Äù, ‚Äútimezone‚Äù, ‚Äúappointment‚Äù, and ‚Äúprocrastinate‚Äù more easily. Every precedent has been tried and this one‚Äôs not the worst.

content.body: But yes, if we did not tend to conflate Time with wall-clock time by default, Time would be a better name for the namespace.

content.body: hmm, I agree that all committee members should be able to bring things up for discussion, but I don't think we'll get consensus on a process change which would require an additional consensus-seeking step which marks "shippability". I was hoping that this could be more like a documentation improvement, process-wise and not even require discussion in a meeting (more like encourage notification but not necessarily synchronized with meetings).

content.body: in general, proposal authors can go about editing their proposals pre-Stage 3 without committee consensus, and even after Stage 3, only normative changes require consensus (whereas this is sort of editorial). Committee consensus (which is the only time it makes sense to talk about "objectors") is only required at stage advancement or consideration of normative PRs (including to Stage 3 proposals)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: in general, proposal authors can go about editing their proposals pre-Stage 3 without committee consensus, and even after Stage 3, only normative changes require consensus (whereas this is sort of editorial). Committee consensus (which is the only time it makes sense to talk about "objectors") is only required at stage advancement or consideration of normative PRs (including to Stage 3 proposals)

content.body: (I'm not sure how to interpret "needs"--who would this be an obligation on, and how would we judge whether we're in the state of needing that? But any delegate who thinks they have something important to discuss *can* do so.)
